perturbation.original_text: Each of SMBC/Nikko and Moelis Holdings agrees not to solicit or hire any employee of the other party during the term of this Agreement and for a period of 12 months thereafter; provided, however, that the foregoing restriction shall not apply to general solicitations to the public that are not specifically directed to employees of other party (or employment of applicants to such solicitations). Each of SMBC/Nikko and Moelis Holdings agrees, during the term of this Agreement (except pursuant to this Agreement) and for a period of 12 months thereafter, not to solicit any Client Introduced by the other party in connection with an assignment on Covered Businesses involving Japanese Companies where all principal parties involved are located within Covered Regions.
perturbation.changed_text: Each of SMBC/Nikko and Moelis Holdings agrees not to solicit or hire any employee of the other party during the term of this Agreement and for a period of 36 months thereafter; provided, however, that the foregoing restriction shall not apply to general solicitations to the public that are not specifically directed to employees of other party (or employment of applicants to such solicitations). Each of SMBC/Nikko and Moelis Holdings agrees, during the term of this Agreement (except pursuant to this Agreement) and for a period of 36 months thereafter, not to solicit any Client Introduced by the other party in connection with an assignment on Covered Businesses involving Japanese Companies where all principal parties involved are located within Covered Regions.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the non-solicitation period to 36 months may be deemed overly broad and unreasonable in some jurisdictions, potentially conflicting with state laws regarding employee mobility and trade restrictions. California, for example, generally disfavors non-compete agreements and restrictions on employment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Varies by state, potential conflict with California Business and Professions Code Section 16600 and similar state laws.

perturbation.original_text: This Section 10.1 shall terminate with respect to Confidential Information relating to a (prospective) Client, two years following receipt of such information, and with respect to any other Confidential Information, two years following the termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: This Section 10.1 shall terminate with respect to Confidential Information relating to a (prospective) Client, one year following receipt of such information, and with respect to any other Confidential Information, one year following the termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period to one year for all confidential information could be deemed insufficient to protect trade secrets or other sensitive business information, particularly in industries where information has a longer useful life, this could contradict common business practices and potentially lead to legal challenges based on inadequate protection of proprietary information.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Varies by state, but potentially conflicts with trade secret laws like the Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA) or state equivalents if the shorter period fails to provide reasonable protection.

perturbation.original_text: At the end of such initial term, and any renewed term, as applicable, this Agreement shall automatically renew for an additional one (1) year term, unless a party provides written notice to the other parties at least six (6) months prior to the end of the initial term. At any time during a renewed term, this Agreement may be terminated by any party on six (6) months prior notice that it wishes to terminate the Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: At the end of such initial term, and any renewed term, as applicable, this Agreement shall automatically renew for an additional one (1) year term, unless a party provides written notice to the other parties at least one (1) months prior to the end of the initial term. At any time during a renewed term, this Agreement may be terminated by any party on one (1) months prior notice that it wishes to terminate the Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for non-renewal or termination to one month may be considered commercially unreasonable, especially given the strategic nature of the alliance and the potential disruption caused by a sudden termination. This short notice period could be seen as violating the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing present in most contracts under United States Law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied duty of good faith and fair dealing, principles of contract law regarding commercially reasonable notice periods.
